Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for Young Investigators to Attend the 24th International Meshing Roundtable

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in the 24th International Meshing Roundtable (IMR) on October 11-14, 2015 in Austin, TX. Meshing is the decomposition of complex objects into simple parts for design, display, and analysis. As technologies change in computing and computer-aided design and manufacturing the demand for meshing seems only to increase.

The IMR conference includes four short courses, four invited speakers, and presentations of reviewed papers, research notes, and posters, and a professional development session particularly targetting students and postdocs. This award will support registration and some travel expenses for a dozen students (undergraduate to postdoctoral, coming from U.S. universities, national labs, or non-profit research organizations) to exchange ideas with experts from around the world, fostering collaboration and recognition that can help them launch their careers. (For selection criteria, see the conference web site: http://www.sandia.gov/imr/)

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported travel of 12 U.S.-based graduate students and postdoctoral fellows to the International Meshing Roundtable (IMR) conference.The participants presented regular papers, research notes, and posters.

The topics for discussion at the conference include the following: CAD and computational geometry issues for meshing, mesh generation and modification, meshing for high-performance and distributed computing, and implications of applications for meshing (finite element, finite volume analysis and modeling, geometric modeling, computer graphics and scientific visualization, and others).

The IMR offers excellent educational opportunities for students who are working on the meshing research and related applications. The conference includes short courses, invited talks, a banquet with a speaker,  presentation of conference papers, presentation of research notes, a poster session, and a professional development session targeting students and postdocs. These activities  enhance the interactions between many NSF funded researchers, experts in mesh generation and geometry from around the world, and the awardees of this project.

The supported students and postdocs have the opportunity to attend a short course in meshing where the lecturers are internationally known experts in mesh generation. The instructors address both theoretical and practical problems for the design and implementation of grid generation algorithms and software. The course is ideal for graduate students that are just entering the field and for advanced graduate and postdoctoral students that want to expand their current skills and knowledge.

To help students and postdocs build their professional development skills and knowledge in the research community, the committee organized a professional development session geared specifically for this audience. Speakers were invited from academia, national labs and industry to share their personal experiences, and to discuss job hunting in the field, setting a research agenda, and professional networking.

The IMR is the primary conference in the field of meshing and its applications. The results presented at IMR are disseminated through conference presentations, published proceedings that are available in open access through an Elsevier online library, the conference web site with proceedings and research notes, and USB sticks given to attendees. The conference published cutting edge developments in meshing that are used in a number of related fields, primarily in modeling and simulation.
